title: Reading Numbers on the Soroban: A Visual Guide for Parents
description: Understanding how to read a soroban is simpler than it looks. Master this and you can help your child with any problem.

content.intro: When you first look at a soroban, it seems like random beads. But there's a simple system. Once you understand it, you can read any number instantly – and help your child when they're stuck.

sections.text: Count only the beads TOUCHING the beam. Beads away from the beam = 0. Upper bead down = 5. Each lower bead up = 1.

items: **5:** Upper bead touching beam, lower beads away

sections.text: Each rod is a place value. Read from left to right, just like regular numbers:
Example: If rod 1 shows 3 and rod 2 shows 4 and rod 3 shows 2, read left to right: 243.

items: Upper bead down, 2 lower beads up → 7
No upper bead, 4 lower beads up → 4
**Counting ALL beads:** Only count beads touching the beam
**Reading right to left:** Read left to right like normal numbers
**Mixing up columns:** Each rod is separate, don't combine beads from different rods

sections.text: Spend 5 minutes learning to read the soroban yourself. It'll make helping your child SO much easier.

faq.question: What if there's no bead at the beam?
faq.answer: That rod shows zero. All beads away from the beam = 0 for that place value.

faq.question: How do I know which rod is ones vs. tens?
faq.answer: The rightmost rod you're using is always the ones place. Many sorobans have a dot on the ones rod (or every third rod) to help.

faq.question: Can a rod show more than 9?
faq.answer: No. Maximum is 9 (upper bead = 5, plus 4 lower beads). This mirrors our base-10 number system perfectly.
